Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CDI-Type II: 4 Dimensional Visualization of Past Ocean Circulation from Paleoceanographic Data
Award.AbstractNarration: One of the fundamental challenges in the study of past climate change in Earth history is how to reconstruct and compare past ocean circulation (as derived from sparse geochemical data collected from fossils in deep-sea sedimentary cores) with modern ocean circulation (as constructed from modern oceanographic observations and computer simulations) to yield insight into the differences and processes governing ocean circulation throughout the last glacial cycle from 150,000 years ago to the present. Similarly, a major challenge in computer science is how to extract information from sparse datasets, and how to effectively combine computational thinking with automated data analysis, to extract new knowledge about features and processes. Our multidisciplinary and multi-institutional project brings together a team of computer scientists, physical oceanographers, paleoceanographers, and computational geophysicists to address these challenges. We are developing an innovative suite of computational tools to explore past changes in global ocean circulation by allowing researchers to interact with data in a 3-dimensional environment across a geologically relevant time domain (the 4th dimension). This project will merge analysis of ocean flow with 40 years of previously-collected geochemical data from deep-sea sedimentary cores in order to gain new insights into past ocean circulation change. Our research will take advantage of the unique analytical resources and interdisciplinary collaborative environment provided by the UC Davis KeckCAVES (W.M. Keck Center for Active Visualization in the Earth Sciences). The KeckCAVES provides immersive interactive visualization technologies that help scientists identify meaningful patterns in complex datasets. In this unique collaborative environment, we are developing methods to improve data interpolation, to extract ocean flow patterns, and to characterize ocean flow over time for potential change detection, along with interactive means of visualizing and interacting with those large and time-dependent datasets. The computational methods developed in this project are adaptable to a wide range of visualization and data-analysis applications for analysis of flow fields. The scientific visualization methods we develop will be used to develop innovative, provocative, and intuitive instructional materials for undergraduate and graduate education; for making other researchers familiar with new scientific methodology (visually-aided analysis); for bringing science and scientific results to the public; and for bringing interactive scientific visualization technology to all of the partner institutions in this collaborative project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project brought together an interdisciplinary team of scientists, primarily from ocean/climate science and computer science. The main purpose of the effort was to develop computer tools for efficient and easy-to-use visual analysis tools for oceanography data, either collected experimentally or created by computer simulation. The tools developed include hardware, such as low-cost immersive visualization systems, and software, such as interactive three-dimensional (3D) visualization methods and tele-presence infrastructure enabling collaborative data analysis done by scientists located at different. The development of these tools was driven by the team’s ocean/climate scientists, who specified necessary features and provided feedback guiding the tools’ refinement. The tools developed by this effort have been made public. Software has been released under open-source licenses.

This project developed new methods in two primary areas: 1) reconstruction of global distributions of geochemical properties from sparse core samples collected from the ocean floor, and 2) collaborative visualization of complex 3D data in virtual reality (VR) environments.

The main outcome in the first research area were scattered data reconstruction methods to convert sparsely sampled data from the global ocean floor, relating positions in the ocean to geochemical properties such as stable isotope ratios. Sampled data was converted to continuous functions, i.e., f(latitude, longitude, depth), defined everywhere inside the global ocean. These methods were evaluated for their ability to reconstruct known globally measured property distributions from sparse subsets of data sampled from the same distributions.

The second research area led to several outcomes. A primary goal in the early phase of the project was to construct low-cost immersive visualization environments at the participating institutions UC Santa Barbara (UCSB) and Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI), to complement the high-end CAVE environment already existing at UC Davis (UCD). The goal was two-fold: 1) to enable researchers at UCSB and WHOI to use immersive visualization software developed by the UC Davis W.M. Keck Center for Active Visualization in the Earth Sciences (KeckCAVES) for the analysis of complex 3D data produced by the project’s data reconstruction effort, and 2) to enable researchers physically located at different sites to collaboratively analyze 3D data over long distances through tele-presence and remote collaboration.

UCD researchers installed custom visualization environments consisting of large-screen stereoscopic 3D TVs and optical 3D tracking systems at UCSB and WHOI, see Figs. 1 and 2. At the time (2012), this was the best option to support a 3D visualization approach that had already been used successfully at KeckCAVES at affordable cost. Practical use during the project’s lifetime showed that these environments were too fragile, in terms of requiring local maintenance expertise to keep them operating and easily sustainable in the long term, beyond the project’s lifetime.

Commodity head-mounted VR displays, such as the Oculus Rift and HTC Vive, became commercially available during the later stage of the project (2015). UCD researchers adapted KeckCAVES software to these new devices, specifically the HTC Vive. While this development could not be deployed at UCSB and WHOI during the period of this project, commodity VR displays are now an affordable and reliable option to make available KeckCAVES visualization technology to third parties. UCSB and WHOI researchers will be able to augment or replace their current visualization environments with commodity VR headsets.

To support joint analysis of 3D data by researchers located at different sites, UCD researchers extended KeckCAVES tele-presence and remote collaboration infrastructure by developing software drivers for 3D camera hardware, such as Microsoft’s second-generation Kinect, and by developing remote collaboration software for KeckCAVES 3D visualization techniques. Due to changing hardware availability and on-going software development, remote collaboration capabilities were not fully deployed at UCSB and WHOI. Remote collaboration capabilities were evaluated at all-hands meetings at UC Davis.
